options.text: The discovery of the New World

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason European rulers were interested in finding Prester John's kingdom?

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Your brain hallucinates your conscious reality - Anil Seth

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main question in the talk?

options.label: A
options.text: How does the brain process sensory information?

options.label: C
options.text: What is the nature of reality?

options.label: D
options.text: What is the relationship between the brain and the body?

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the result of anesthesia on consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a sense of detachment and falling apart

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the prospects of a conscious AI?
According to the speaker, what is the relationship between consciousness and intelligence?

options.label: B
options.text: Consciousness is a result of high intelligence

options.label: C
options.text: Consciousness and intelligence are very different things

options.label: D
options.text: Intelligence is a necessary condition for consciousness

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's strategy for understanding consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the brain and body separately

options.label: B
options.text: To study the properties of consciousness in terms of physics and chemistry

options.label: C
options.text: To study the brain and body together

options.label: D
options.text: To study the philosophy of consciousness

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the role of the brain in perception?

options.label: B
options.text: It actively generates the world we experience

multiple-choice.question: What is the rubber hand illusion, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: An example of a controlled hallucination

options.label: B
options.text: An example of a visual illusion

options.label: C
options.text: An example of a tactile illusion

options.label: D
options.text: An example of a auditory illusion

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is interoception?

options.label: A
options.text: The perception of the external world

options.label: B
options.text: The perception of the internal state of the body

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the relationship between the body and consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: The body is not necessary for consciousness

options.label: B
options.text: The body is necessary for consciousness, but not sufficient

options.label: C
options.text: The body is both necessary and sufficient for consciousness

options.label: D
options.text: The body has no relationship to consciousness

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the result of understanding consciousness in terms of biological mechanisms?

options.label: A
options.text: A greater sense of separation from nature

options.label: B
options.text: A greater sense of wonder and connection to nature

options.label: C
options.text: A greater sense of fear and uncertainty

options.label: D
options.text: A greater sense of control and dominance

title: How one scientist took on the chemical industry - Mark Lytle

multiple-choice.question: In what year did Rachel Carson receive a letter describing songbirds suddenly dropping from tree branches, which sparked her investigation into DDT?

In what year did Rachel Carson become the second woman to be hired at the Bureau of Fisheries full-time?
What was DDT originally used for during World War II?

options.label: A
options.text: To shield crops from insects and protect soldiers from insect-borne diseases

options.label: B
options.text: To eradicate fire ants in the southern U.S.

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate substances capable of catastrophic harm

options.label: D
options.text: To control the threat insects posed to human health

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Eliminating the threat of insect-borne diseases

options.label: D
options.text: Regulating substances capable of catastrophic harm

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: He supported her call to regulate substances capable of catastrophic harm

options.label: B
options.text: It killed wildlife indiscriminately, but did little to eliminate the ants

options.label: C
options.text: It had no impact on the environment or human health

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the evolution of resistant species

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The partial ban on the use of DDT

options.label: D
options.text: The regulation of substances capable of catastrophic harm

title: How can we solve the antibiotic resistance crisis? - Gerry Wright

title: The tale of the doctor who defied Death - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What was the problem faced by the husband and wife in the story?

options.label: A
options.text: They had just lost their thirteenth child.

options.label: B
options.text: They were running out of food and money to support their growing family.

options.label: C
options.text: They were struggling to find a suitable godfather for their child.

options.label: D
options.text: They were facing a severe illness.

multiple-choice.question: Who were the two figures the father encountered in the woods before meeting Death?
Why did the father refuse the offers of God and the Devil to be his child's godfather?

options.label: A
options.text: He was afraid of their power.

options.label: B
options.text: He didn't want his child to be influenced by their judgmental nature.

options.label: C
options.text: He wanted his child to have a mortal godfather.

options.label: D
options.text: He didn't think they were suitable role models.

multiple-choice.question: What gift did Death give to his godson when he came of age?

options.label: B
options.text: A flask containing the cure for all human ailments

multiple-choice.question: What was the condition for using the cure-all potion given by Death?

options.label: A
options.text: It could only be used on patients who were near death.

options.label: B
options.text: It could only be used if Death was not present.

options.label: C
options.text: It could only be used if Death was hovering at the top of the patient's bed.

options.label: D
options.text: It could only be used on patients who were willing to pay a high price.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the doctor try to deceive Death when treating the king?

options.label: A
options.text: He wanted to save the king's life at any cost.

options.label: B
options.text: He wanted to gain more wealth and fame.

options.label: C
options.text: He was afraid of Death's wrath.

options.label: D
options.text: He wanted to prove his skills as a doctor.

multiple-choice.question: What was the consequence of the doctor's attempt to deceive Death?

options.label: A
options.text: Death took away the doctor's healing powers.

options.label: B
options.text: Death warned the doctor that he would pay for it with his life if he cheated again.

options.label: C
options.text: Death took the doctor's wealth and fame.

options.label: D
options.text: Death ended the doctor's life immediately.

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason for the doctor's downfall when treating the princess?

options.label: A
options.text: He was too confident in his abilities.

options.label: B
options.text: He was distracted by his love for the princess.

options.label: C
options.text: He failed to notice Death's presence.

options.label: D
options.text: He used the cure-all potion incorrectly.

multiple-choice.question: What did the candles in the immense cave represent?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of lives the doctor had saved.

options.label: B
options.text: The duration of each person's life.

options.label: C
options.text: The number of people Death had claimed.

multiple-choice.question: What was the final punishment given to the doctor by Death?

options.label: A
options.text: Death took away the doctor's healing powers.

options.label: B
options.text: Death ended the doctor's life by extinguishing his candle.

options.label: D
options.text: Death trapped the doctor in the cave forever.

title: What’s a squillo, and why do opera singers need it? Ming Luke

multiple-choice.question: In Mozart's opera "The Magic Flute," what is notable about the Queen of the Night's singing voice?

options.label: A
options.text: It is unable to be heard above the instruments.

options.label: B
options.text: It requires a microphone to be heard by the audience.

options.label: C
options.text: It can be heard clearly above the instruments without any assistance from a microphone.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only audible to those in the front row.

multiple-choice.question: What is the fundamental in the context of sound vibrations?

options.label: A
options.text: The highest frequency vibration of a note.

options.label: B
options.text: The lowest frequency vibration of a note.

options.label: C
options.text: The combination of multiple vibrations that create a note.

multiple-choice.question: What are harmonics or partials in the context of sound vibrations?

options.label: A
options.text: The fundamental frequency of a note.

options.label: B
options.text: The combination of multiple vibrations that create a note.

options.label: C
options.text: Specific frequencies that layer on top of the fundamental frequency.

multiple-choice.question: Why do different instruments have unique sonic signatures?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they produce different fundamental frequencies.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they produce different harmonic series.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the shape and material of the instrument.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the musician playing the instrument.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to an opera singer's power of projection?

options.label: C
options.text: Targeting a sensory sweet spot where human ears are most sensitive.

multiple-choice.question: What is the range of fundamental frequencies that an operatic soprano can produce?
What is the term for the distinctive ringing timbre that opera singers aim to produce?
How do opera singers produce higher frequencies and accentuate certain overtones?

options.label: A
options.text: By modifying the shape and tension in their vocal folds and vocal tract.

options.label: B
options.text: By shifting the position of their tongues and lips.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of vibrato in singing?

options.label: B
options.text: To produce a fuller sound that rings out over the instruments.

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the volume of the singer's voice.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that the concert hall helps opera singers project their voices?

options.label: B
options.text: By reflecting sound waves towards the audience.

options.label: D
options.text: By reducing the volume of the orchestra.

title: Why germs thrive on planes— and how to stop them - Raymond Wang

options.label: C
